thread.title: Oregon Fish and Wildlife Columbia River fishing reports
thread.title_full: Oregon Fish and Wildlife Columbia River fishing reports | The Seattle Times

author: Mark Yuasa
title: Oregon Fish and Wildlife Columbia River fishing reports
text:
COLUMBIA FISHING REPORTS

Weekend Fishing Opportunities: 
The fall salmon season is open from Buoy 10 upstream to the Oregon/Washington Border above McNary Dam (see Sport Fishing Regulation Updates page for retention details). An estimated 1,192,700 (129% of projected) fall Chinook and 539,600 coho are expected to return to the Columbia River this fall. White sturgeon retention is closed from Buoy 10 upstream to the Oregon/Washington Border above McNary Dam, but remains an option for catch and release fishing. Walleye angling is good in Troutdale. Salmon, Steelhead and Shad

On the lower Columbia this past weekend there were 239 salmonid boats and 28 Oregon bank anglers counted from Bonneville Dam downstream to Longview on Saturday’s (10/10) flight. In the gorge, boat anglers averaged 2.61 fall Chinook, 0.10 coho and 0.06 steelhead caught per boat, while anglers fishing in Troutdale averaged 0.41 fall Chinook and 0.02 coho caught per boat. In the Portland to Tongue Point area, boat anglers averaged 0.33 fall Chinook, 0.11 coho and 0.03 steelhead caught per boat. Bank anglers fishing in the gorge averaged 0.12 fall Chinook and 0.02 coho caught per angler, while anglers fishing the Portland to Westport area averaged 0.13 fall Chinook caught per angler.
Most Read Stories Seahawks fullback Derrick Coleman arrested for investigation of hit, run Outraged Seattle Public Schools parents, pace yourselves Police: Woman linked to 1973 disappearance is actually alive Seattle Seahawks release WR B.J. Daniels, RB Rod Smith Mayor wants developer off project, cites violation of city values Unlimited Digital Access. $1 for 4 weeks. Gorge Bank: 
Weekend checking showed five adult and one jack fall Chinook kept; plus one adult coho released for 42 bank anglers.
Gorge Boats: 
Weekend checking showed 79 adult fall Chinook, six jack fall Chinook, two adult coho and two steelhead kept; plus two adult fall Chinook and one adult coho released for 31 boats (103 anglers).
Troutdale Boats: 
Weekend checking showed 26 adult and three jack fall Chinook kept; plus one adult fall Chinook and one adult coho released for 66 boats (139 anglers).
Portland to Westport Bank 
Weekend checking showed two adult fall Chinook kept for 16 bank anglers.
Portland to Tongue Point Boats: 
Weekend checking showed 21 adult fall Chinook, one jack fall Chinook, four adult coho, one jack coho and one steelhead kept; plus one steelhead and three coho released for 63 boats (128 anglers).
Bonneville Pool (Columbia River between Bonneville Dam and The Dalles Dam): 
No report.
John Day Pool (Columbia River above John Day Dam and John Day Arm): 
Weekly checking showed three steelhead and two Chinook kept; plus five steelhead released for 32 boats.
STURGEON 
Lower Columbia (below Bonneville Dam): 
Closed to retention, catch-and-release only. Weekly checking showed three legal white sturgeon released for one boat (two anglers).
Bonneville Dam upstream to the Oregon/Washington Border: 
Closed to retention, catch-and-release only.
WALLEYE 
Gorge: 
Weekly checking showed no catch for one boat (two anglers).
Troutdale: 
Weekly checking showed nine walleye released for two boats (three anglers).
Portland to Westport: 
No report.
 
Mark Yuasa : 206-464-8780 or myuasa@seattletimes.com ; on Twitter: @markkyuasa . Mark Yuasa covers fishing and outdoors in the Pacific Northwest.
